Graphical abstract This review mainly introduces the latest advances in electro-Fenton technology, including the regulation of electrocatalysts, optimization of reaction conditions, and the application of electro-Fenton reaction in coupling technologies. The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) holds significant potential for various energy conversion and utilization technologies. In particular, the two-electron (2e−) ORR process for the electro-synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) facilitates the continuous production of this compound. Recently, the application of 2e− ORR in electro-Fenton (EF) technology has garnered substantial attention within the wastewater treatment sector. Despite substantial advancements, challenges remain regarding the activity and stability of oxygen reduction catalysts, as well as the specific reaction conditions, which continue to limit the degradation efficiency of EF technology. Therefore, it is essential to examine the progress in research on 2e− oxygen reduction catalysts and the optimization of EF reaction conditions. This review begins by summarizing the fundamental principles of ORR and EF technologies. It discusses the regulatory strategies for carbon-based and transition metal-based catalysts aimed at improving the yield and selectivity of H2O2. Additionally, the optimization methods for EF reaction conditions are outlined, focusing on promoting the regeneration of Fe2+ and broadening the operational pH range. The review further elaborates on novel coupling technologies. Finally, it envisions future research prospects to enhance the practicality and feasibility of EF technology in wastewater treatment. Keywords Oxygen reduction reaction Electro-Fenton technology Non-noble electrocatalyst Regulation strategies 1 Introduction In light of the increasing energy and environmental challenges, the development and utilization of clean energy technologies have become imperative. Currently, a variety of energy conversion and utilization technologies have been developed. The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) demonstrates significant potential for application across multiple domains of energy conversion and utilization, including fuel cells and metal-air batteries [1–3]. Furthermore, ORR is also applicable to the electro-synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), which is widely used in medical disinfection, chemical synthesis, and wastewater treatment, and serves as a potential energy carrier [4–6]. Importantly, the production of H2O2 via the ORR follows a two-electron (2e−) reaction pathway. This approach is more cost-effective, safer, and environmentally friendly compared to the conventional anthraquinone method [7–9]. Notably, recently developed electro-Fenton (EF) technology synthesizes H2O2 in situ through a direct 2e− ORR occurring on the surface of non-noble metal cathode catalysts [10,11]. This process is followed by an activation cycle between Fe2+/Fe3+ and H2O2, leading to the generation of hydroxyl radicals ( OH) [12,13]. These radicals readily participate in non-selective chain reactions with electron-rich organic compounds, resulting in their complete mineralization into H2O and CO2 through hydroxylation and dehydrogenation reactions [14–16]. Therefore, the application of 2e− ORR to EF technology has drawn widespread attention in the field of wastewater treatment [17]. The in-situ generation and activation of H2O2 on the surface of oxygen reduction catalysts contribute to the advantages of EF technology, which include simple equipment and operation, high cost-effectiveness, and enhanced safety and environmental friendliness [18–20]. Nevertheless, it still encounters certain limitations. For example, the ORR catalyzed by the cathode catalyst involves a complex multi-electron transfer process, characterized by a competitive relationship between the 2e− and four-electron (4e−) ORR pathways, which ultimately diminishes the selectivity and yield of H2O2 [21,22]. Additionally, the ORR entails a gas–liquid-solid three-phase reaction interface. The microenvironment at this interface significantly influences the adsorption, diffusion, and electron transfer of O2 and the intermediate (OOH*), thereby increasing electronic diffusion resistance [23,24]. Moreover, the durability of current 2e− ORR catalysts is inadequate following multiple cycles [25,26]. Therefore, advancing EF technology hinges on the design of highly efficient and stable 2e− ORR electrocatalysts, as well as a comprehensive understanding of the reaction mechanism and the optimization of practical degradation conditions. In recent years, researchers have made substantial progress in the development of 2e− ORR catalysts and the optimization of EF reaction conditions. Consequently, a comprehensive review of these advancements is crucial. This review begins by introducing the fundamental principles of ORR and EF technology. It then summarizes regulation strategies for 2e− ORR electrocatalysts and methods for optimizing reaction conditions. Finally, the applications of various combined technologies in this field are discussed, along with prospects for the future development of EF technology. It is anticipated that this review will offer valuable insights and ideas for the continued advancement of EF technology. 2 Basic concepts 2.1 Fundamentals The EF technology, which is based on electrochemical oxidation, originated in the 1980s and is currently recognized as a highly esteemed advanced oxidation technology. The EF process has been successfully applied to treat a variety of common environmental pollutants, including pharmaceutical wastewater [27], dye wastewater [28], phenolic compounds [29], and waste leachate [30]. The EF system requires the introduction of O2, leading to the generation of H2O2 on the surface of suitable cathode materials through a 2e− ORR, as depicted in Eq. (1). The H2O2 produced in situ at the cathode can then react with Fe2+ in solution, yielding strong oxidizing OH, according to Eq. (2). Additionally, Fe3+ generated after H2O2 activation can be reduced back to Fe2+ on the cathode surface, facilitating iron recycling, as shown in Eq. (3). This process enables the continuous activation of H2O2 and results in the generation of a substantial quantity of OH [31–34]. Furthermore, according to Eqs. (4)–(11), the generation of OH typically accompanies the production of other reactive oxygen species (1O2, O2 − , HO2 ). Although the oxidation properties of these species are weaker than those of OH, they are capable of decomposing organic matter into smaller molecular intermediate products, ultimately leading to complete mineralization into H2O and CO2 [35–37]. However, the mutual conversion among various reactive oxygen species (ROS) can affect their concentrations and distributions, thereby further influencing degradation efficiency. If the conversion process results in the generation of more highly oxidative radicals, degradation efficiency is likely to increase. Conversely, if fewer or weaker oxidative radicals are produced, degradation efficiency may decrease. Therefore, when applying the EF system, it is necessary to optimize reaction conditions to maximize the generation and utilization of strongly oxidizing OH while minimizing the production and interference of unfavorable ROS. In the context of the ORR, oxygen can undergo electrochemical reduction to H2O2 via a 2e− pathway or to H2O through a 4e− pathway, as illustrated in Eq. (13). This represents an unavoidable side reaction within the EF system, significantly influencing H2O2 production and consequently leading to a marked decrease in EF efficiency [22,38–40]. Therefore, the selective generation of H2O2 is crucial for enhancing the efficiency of the EF process. Designing and constructing novel electrocatalysts with high activity and selectivity for the 2e− ORR remains a significant challenge. In addition to the competing effects of the 4e− process, there are several concurrent reactions occurring within the system. When there is an excess of H2O2 and Fe2+, the surplus H2O2 can readily convert to HO2 , which possesses a slightly weaker oxidizing ability than OH (Eq. (4)), and can also undergo its own disproportionation reaction (Eq. (14)) [41,42]. Simultaneously, the excess Fe2+ consumes the generated OH (Eq. (15)), highlighting the need to optimize the H2O2/Fe2+ concentration ratio in the EF reaction [43]. Furthermore, the reaction at the anode promotes the oxidation of water molecules into oxygen, thereby increasing the oxygen content within the EF system and enhancing H2O2 generation at the cathode surface. This ultimately leads to elevated levels of OH and improved Fenton efficiency [44]. (1) O2 + 2H+ + 2e− → H2O2 (2) Fe2+ + H2O2 → Fe3+ + OH + OH− (3) Fe3+ + e− → Fe2+ (4) H2O2 + OH → H2O + HO2 (5) O2 + e− → O2 − (6) O2 − + e− + 2H+ → H2O2 (7) O2 − + H+ ⇄ HO2 (8) 2HO2 → H2O2 + O2 (9) 2O2 − + 2H+ → H2O2 + 1O2 (10) O2 − + OH → OH− + 1O2 (11) HO2 + OH → H2O + 1O2 (12) OH/1O2/O2 − /HO2 + organics → intermediates → CO2 + H2O (13) O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O (14) 2H2O2 → O2 + 2H2O (15) Fe2+ + OH → Fe3+ + OH− The performance of EF is determined not only by the generation of H2O2 and OH but also by the rate of Fe2+ regeneration [45]. In conventional EF, the rapid consumption (as described in Eq. (2)) and the slow regeneration (according to Eq. (3)) of Fe2+create a significant imbalance, leading to sluggish OH accumulation and exacerbating the problem of iron sludge precipitation [46]. Therefore, prioritizing selectivity for H2O2 becomes increasingly crucial, considering energy consumption and facilitating Fe2+/Fe3+ recycling to enhance the application potential of EF. Generally, the ORR can proceed through either a 2e− or 4e− pathway, with the competition between these pathways serving as the primary determinant of H2O2 selectivity [47–49]. The 2e− ORR consists of two reaction steps, as shown below. (16) * + O2(g) + H+ + e− → OOH* (17) OOH* + H+ + e− → * + H2O2 (l) The 4e− ORR consists of four reaction steps, as shown below. (18) * + O2 (g) + H+ + e− → OOH* (19) OOH* + H+ + e− → O* + H2O (l) (20) O* + H+ + e− → OH* (21) OH* + H+ + e− → * + H2O (l) where * denotes the adsorption site, while OOH*, O*, and OH* represent different adsorption intermediates. The reaction path diagrams for 2e− and 4e− in Fig. 1 (a) illustrate that, in addition to evaluating the activity and stability of electrocatalyst materials, achieving high selectivity towards the target reaction pathway is essential for enhancing the selectivity of the 2e− ORR [50]. The rate-determining step (RDS) of the 2e− ORR is the transition from OOH* to H2O2, and both its selectivity and activity are significantly influenced by the adsorption energy of the OOH* on the catalyst, as well as the stability of the OO bond [48]. It is crucial to optimize the interaction between OOH* and the catalytic center to maintain a delicate balance, avoiding both excessive and insufficient binding. Excessive binding may lead to the cleavage of the OO bond in OOH*, resulting in the formation of the reduced product H2O. Conversely, insufficient binding can create insurmountably high reaction barriers, thereby diminishing ORR activity [51,52]. Consequently, the adsorption free energy of OOH* (ΔG OOH*) has emerged as a highly significant descriptor that effectively reflects the selectivity of the 2e− ORR. As proposed by Rossmeisl et al. in their earlier studies, regulating ΔG OOH* allows for the identification of optimal catalytic materials, which can maintain high selectivity while simultaneously exhibiting excellent activity. This finding provides a theoretical foundation for the design of efficient 2e− ORR catalysts and informs subsequent research directions [47,48]. Ideally, the optimal value of ΔG OOH* for 2e− ORR would be 4.22 eV at U = 0 V (or 3.52 eV at U = 0.70 V), while a close-to-optimal ΔG OOH* for 4e− ORR should be approximately 3.9 eV [47,53,54]. Additionally, the thermodynamic limiting potential (U L), defined as the highest reduction potential when all reaction step-free energies have decreased, can be utilized alongside ΔG OOH* to estimate the relative activity between 2e− ORR and 4e− ORR. For efficient performance in ORR, an ideal catalyst should exhibit a positive U L close to the equilibrium potential U 0 (O2/H2O2) = 0.70 V for 2e− process or U 0 (O2/H2O) = 1.23 V for 4e− process. The difference between the U 0 and U L is referred to as the theoretical overpotential (η = U 0 − U L), with the η for the generation of H2O2 by excellent 2e− ORR catalysts ideally being 0 eV [47,54,55]. The U L values for O2/H2O2 of various metal porphyrins were calculated by Zhao et al [47]. Notably, porphyrin cobalt displays a η (O2/H2O2) value of 0.04 V, rendering it highly favorable for 2e− ORR, whereas porphyrin rhodium exhibits a η (O2/H2O) value of 0.23 V, making it particularly suitable for 4e− ORR. Therefore, comparing ΔG OOH* and η enables a more precise assessment of ORR selectivity. The volcano plot of different metal-based catalysts for ORR is illustrated in Fig. 1(b) [49]. The relationship curve between U L and ΔG OOH* allows for a clear distinction between the ease or difficulty of the 2e− and 4e− reaction pathways based on variations in U L, ΔG OOH*, and η. Fig. 1(c and d) illustrates the Sabatier volcano free energy plots, which depict the adsorption energy of OOH* by various oxygen-containing functional groups (OFGs) [56]. It is evident that for the 2e− ORR, when ΔG OOH* is positioned at the apex of the volcano diagram, it signifies the optimal catalytic activity of the catalyst. Notably, if it is located on the left side of the volcano, it indicates a strong binding affinity between the catalyst surface and OOH*, thereby impeding its reduction to H2O2. In contrast, placement on the right side of the volcano suggests a weak binding affinity, which hinders the reduction of O2 to OOH*. Consequently, CoGCOC exhibits superior ΔG OOH* values and free energy levels, demonstrating exceptional performance in the 2e− ORR. Additionally, a similar conclusion can be drawn from Fig. 1(e) [48]. This study evaluated the activity trend of CoS x by constructing a model for the adsorption of OOH* on CoS x , based on changes in the free energy of OOH* and ORR volcano plots at the equilibrium potential of 0.70 V. The results indicated that CoS4 exhibited the best adsorption performance for OOH* (ΔG OOH*: 4.18 eV; η: 0.018 V), minimizing the reaction potential for the electrochemical reduction of O2 to H2O2 and accelerating the reaction kinetics. Thus, evaluating relevant ΔG OOH*, U L, and η can provide valuable guidance for the design and synthesis of catalysts for efficient 2e− ORR. 2.2 Classification Fenton oxidation is widely utilized for the degradation and treatment of hazardous organic pollutants, primarily relying on the reaction between H2O2 and Fe2+ to generate a potent non-selective oxidizing agent. In the EF system, H2O2 is generated through the reduction of dissolved oxygen at the cathode surface, while Fe2+ can be added directly or obtained through the oxidation of a sacrificial iron anode [57]. Typically, based on the source of Fe2+ in the system, EF technology can be classified into homogeneous EF and heterogeneous EF. 2.2.1 Homogeneous electro-Fenton The direct addition of water-soluble Fe2+ initiates the homogeneous EF process, and they act as catalysts within the reaction system. These catalysts can take the form of iron salts or complexes consisting of iron and other ligands. They activate H2O2 to generate OH, which is essential for the degradation of organic pollutants [58,59]. Due to its high mass transfer efficiency and the absence of interphase mass transfer resistance, homogeneous EF has been extensively utilized for water pollution control and treatment. For instance, O2 generates H2O2 in situ through the surface of MnO2 electrodes prepared on graphite substrates via a 2e− ORR [60]. Most of the H2O2 is subsequently activated by Fe2+ in the solution to produce OH for the EF process. As a result, the chemical oxygen demand (COD) in the treated wastewater was reduced by 88.01%, significantly improving the removal rate. However, under alkaline conditions in the homogeneous EF process, a considerable amount of iron sludge is generated. This not only impedes the cyclic regeneration of Fe2+, but also obstructs the active sites on the catalyst due to excessive colloidal matter, thereby diminishing reaction efficiency [61]. Additionally, this sludge poses a risk of secondary environmental pollution and complicates catalyst recycling. Furthermore, pH levels significantly influence operating costs and treatment effectiveness, representing a primary limitation in the homogeneous Fenton system [62,63]. 2.2.2 Heterogeneous electro-Fenton To address the limitations of homogeneous EF systems and to sustain the catalytic activity of H2O2 and oxidative degradation of OH, heterogeneous EF has emerged as a promising alternative in recent years. This approach involves the immobilization of catalyst metal ions within a solid carrier structure, enabling catalytic reactions to occur on the surface of the carrier [32,64]. Various materials, including nano zero-valent iron, iron oxide minerals (such as hematite and magnetite), and iron-containing zeolites, have been employed to activate H2O2 and produce highly reactive and non-selective OH [65]. Additionally, active metal components can be loaded onto stable materials like hydrophobic silica oxides, clays, zeolites, mesoporous carbon, and activated carbon, which serve as solid-phase support carriers for catalysts [61]. For example, Cao et al. developed a bifunctional FeO x /NHPC catalyst for the construction of a heterogeneous EF system [66]. The H2O2 generated in situ on the catalytic surface was directly activated to OH via surface iron ions, facilitating the degradation and mineralization of phenol in a neutral reaction solution. Furthermore, Ye et al. explored the innovative application of FeS2/C nanocomposites as efficient, stable, and recyclable catalysts for the heterogeneous EF treatment of organic water pollutants [67]. Under near-neutral pH conditions, the catalytic activity and stability of this heterogeneous material are significantly enhanced due to the reduced content of water-soluble iron ions. These heterogeneous Fenton systems demonstrate improved capabilities for organic pollutant degradation across a broader pH range. They effectively address challenges related to the formation of iron-containing sludge and the deactivation or loss of catalysts commonly encountered in homogeneous Fenton reactions. Furthermore, the separation and recovery of heterogeneous catalysts are more straightforward, facilitating regeneration and recycling without causing secondary pollution. These advantages enhance catalyst utilization efficiency, thereby effectively mitigating the shortcomings of homogeneous reaction processes [68–70]. Consequently, there is an increasing interest in heterogeneous EF reactions. In general, the production of OH in EF systems can occur through both homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions, which are not entirely independent [65]. In a homogeneous EF system, iron species may adhere to the cathode surface, resulting in a process similar to heterogeneous OH production. Conversely, in iron-based heterogeneous EF systems, some dissolution of iron inevitably occurs, contributing to the homogeneous OH production process [71]. Therefore, it is evident that an interaction exists between the principles governing homogeneous and heterogeneous EF processes. Exploring these interactions could provide valuable insights for further research. 3 Electrocatalysts The EF process effectively mitigates the limitations associated with traditional Fenton technology, which necessitates the continuous addition of raw materials and incurs high costs. In contrast, the EF process is characterized by its low cost and environmental friendliness, making it highly applicable in industrial wastewater treatment. A highly active and stable electrocatalyst is crucial for the ORR within the EF framework. In recent years, there has been a proliferation of novel nanoscale catalysts specifically designed for selective H2O2 production, which aligns with the requirements of the Fenton process. Furthermore, these developments have prompted investigations into the mechanistic aspects of the 2e− ORR, including rational catalyst design and potential applications. Currently, carbon-based and transition metal-based catalysts are extensively utilized as 2e− catalysts due to their distinct advantages [72]. This section will concentrate on strategies for designing and optimizing these catalysts to enhance selectivity for H2O2, thereby significantly improving the efficacy of the Fenton process. 3.1 Carbon-based catalysts As previously mentioned, for effective 2e− catalysts, their catalytic surfaces must exhibit appropriate adsorption energies for OOH*. In the context of 2e− ORR, carbon-based materials have been extensively studied as cathode substrates due to their abundant reserves, wide availability, economic viability, and large surface area [73–76]. The activity and selectivity of carbon-based catalysts are closely linked to their electronic structure, where an optimal electronic configuration can enhance the binding of reaction intermediates on the catalytic surface. Recent studies have reported that doping with heteroatoms and incorporating OFGs are effective strategies for improving the electrocatalytic performance of carbon-based electrocatalysts by modulating the adsorption process of OOH* on their surface. This approach ultimately boosts the activity of the 2e− ORR and enhances the selectivity for H2O2 [56]. 3.1.1 Heteroatom doping Recent studies have demonstrated the exceptional electrochemical synthesis properties of carbon-based catalysts for H2O2. Among these, the surface modification of carbon-based materials through heteroatom doping has emerged as an effective strategy [77]. The incorporation of single or multiple non-metallic heteroatoms with elevated electronegativity, such as N, P, S, and B, onto the surface of carbon-based materials can significantly alter the electronic structures and chemical environments of adjacent carbon atoms (Fig. 2 a) [78]. This alteration substantially impacts the charge distribution across carbon planes and influences the adsorption energy of OOH*, thereby enhancing the 2e− ORR activity and accelerating H2O2 generation [79]. N-doped carbon materials have emerged as extensively studied cathode materials for the ORR. It has been demonstrated that N atoms possess higher electronegativity than carbon atoms, resulting in charge redistribution and electronic activation [80]. Consequently, this alteration affects the adsorption behavior of OOH* on carbon materials and promotes the formation of H2O2, thereby serving as an effective strategy to enhance both the catalytic activity and 2e− ORR selectivity of carbon cathodes. For instance, Liu and Luo et al. successfully prepared N-doped porous biochar electrocatalysts (HMC-x) from peanut shell waste [31]. Their findings indicated that the N dopant enhanced the 2e− ORR activity of carbon catalysts by reducing the free energy associated with the formation of OOH*. When HMC-3 was applied to the EF system, bisphenol A (20 mg L−1) was completely removed within 15 min under degradation conditions of pH = 3.0 and U = − 0.7 V. Even after 25 consecutive cycles, bisphenol A (BPA) was completely degraded within 20 min. After the used HMC-3 cathode surface was rinsed with 3 M H2SO4 solution, its kinetic constant (0.34 min−1) nearly reverted to its initial value. This suggests that the hydrated oxide layer and other by-products deposited on the catalyst surface might have obstructed the active sites. Additionally, recent studies have shown that N-modified carbon materials can be tailored by controlling the thermal decomposition temperature to exhibit abundant nitrogen functional groups and improved electrochemical activity. For example, adjusting the thermal decomposition temperature facilitates the preparation of N-doped graphene (N-GE) catalysts, in which the introduction of N elements into the graphene structure not only leads to electronic regulation effects but also results in a larger specific surface area and a porous structure within a certain range of thermal decomposition temperatures [81]. Additionally, the incorporation of N atoms into the graphene lattice creates electron-rich regions that enhance the adsorption and activation of oxygen molecules. Furthermore, the coordinated N atoms can disrupt the original π-electron conjugation system of graphene, forming localized electronic states and thus creating new active sites for the ORR [82]. A heterostructure of ZnO/N-doped graphene (ZnO-NG) was successfully synthesized using a straightforward thermal decomposition process [83]. Research indicated that the interfacial bridging N regulated local electronic distribution, transferring unpaired electrons from Zn sites to adjacent N/C atoms, thereby influencing catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 2b, the ZnO-NG catalyst was positioned near the peak of the volcano plot, exhibiting a ΔG OOH* value of 4.21 eV. Overall, the excellent 2e− ORR selectivity on ZnO-NG can be attributed to the interface ZnN bond regulation of the oxygen reduction pathway, promoting the hydrogenation step from O2 to OOH*, while inhibiting the conversion from O* to OH* (Fig. 2c), thus enhancing the selectivity for 2e− ORR in water restoration. In comparison to N atoms, P atoms exhibit larger atomic radii and a higher electron-donating capacity [84]. For instance, P-doped CoN4-PC was synthesized using the aggregation pyrolysis method for the electrochemical generation of H2O2 [78]. As illustrated in Fig. 2(d and e), the formation of CP bonds effectively induced the stretching of CoN bonds in CoN4, resulting in reduced electron density on Co atoms and optimized adsorption of OOH* at the active sites. With a selectivity exceeding 90%, the catalytic efficiency was significantly enhanced in alkaline electrolytes. Conversely, the covalent radius of the B atom (0.82 Å) is larger than that of N (0.75 Å) and C (0.77 Å), which facilitates the expansion of interlayer space, promotes electron and ion transfer, and enhances the adsorption of the OOH* intermediate [68,85]. Recently, researchers have investigated the potential of B atoms to enhance the catalytic activity of B-doped carbon by tuning doping configurations and sites, as well as their role in charge modulation. Byeon et al. demonstrated that CO2-derived edge B-doped porous carbon (E-BPC) can efficiently electrochemically generate controllable levels of H2O2 across a wide range of doping configurations [86]. Density functional theory (DFT) analysis (Fig. 2f and g) revealed that B doping at edge sites is more favorable than on the basal surface. The oxygenated B-dopant configurations at the edge sites (BC2O armchair edges and BCO2 serrated edges) served as active sites for H2O2 generation, thereby contributing to the design of efficient B-doped carbon materials for H2O2 generation via the 2e− ORR in electrochemistry. Aside from single heteroatom doping, the effective co-doping of heteroatoms can induce synergistic effects, optimize the electronic structure of materials, enhance the availability of active sites, and improve overall performance. For instance, Chen et al. fabricated N,P co-doped porous carbon (MEP-X) using a bifunctional salt strategy [87]. They adjusted the proportions of N and P heteroatoms, along with the content of active substances (pyrrole-N and P-C), to enhance the 2e− ORR activity and degradation efficiency (Fig. 2h). Consequently, the modulation of active species containing P and N effectively improves 2e− ORR selectivity and facilitates the preparation of Fenton catalysts with exceptional activity. In the study conducted by Yang et al., Co-SAC confined within B,N co-doped defective carbon nanotubes (Co-B,N-CNTs) exhibited remarkable activity towards the 2e− ORR pathway for H2O2 generation, achieving a selectivity of approximately 80% in HClO4, with yields reaching as high as 1508 mmol L−1 gcat−1 [85]. These results suggested that the introduction of B atoms in an electron-deficient state modifies the electron distribution around the Co-N x -C sites, thereby enhancing the binding energy with the OOH* intermediates. In the carbon-based cathode, the 2e− ORR can be enhanced through N and S co-doping, which regulates the adsorption energy of O2 and the binding capacity of OOH* [88]. End-on O2 adsorption can be facilitated by modulating the electronic properties via N doping, while S doping can adjust the binding energy of OOH* by altering the spin density. The optimized N,S co-doped graphene demonstrated a reduction in O2 adsorption energy to −2.24 eV (Fig. 2i), which promoted the desorption of OOH* due to changes in the length of the OO/CO bond, resulting in a 42.47% increase in H2O2 accumulation. Yan et al. synthesized high-performance Fenton catalysts from N,S co-doped carbon nanofibers using Sb2S3 templates, achieving high selectivity (97.2%) and mass activity (114.9 A g−1 at 0.65 V) [89]. Their findings indicated that the synergistic effect of the N coordination structure and the S dopant effectively tunes the electronic structure, thereby influencing its interaction with the intermediate OOH* to enhance catalytic activity. In general, N doping has been extensively studied in the context of enhancing catalytic activity. The incorporation of pyridine-N, pyrrole-N, and graphitic-N species can improve charge transfer and increase the density of active sites, which is particularly advantageous for catalytic performance. However, excessive N doping may lead to an increased content of structural defects, create steric hindrance, and reduce the stability and conductivity of the material. B doping can generate electron-deficient sites that promote the adsorption of reactants, thereby enhancing the efficiency of catalytic reactions. S doping is often employed in co-doping strategies, as its presence can significantly alter the electronic structure of the carbon substrate, further improving the catalytic performance of N-doped carbon materials. Nonetheless, S has a tendency to act as a catalytic poison, which can hinder the catalytic process. P is also frequently utilized in co-doping to achieve a synergistic effect. With an atomic radius of 1.10 Å, P is similar to that of S (1.02 Å), and its doping content must be optimized to prevent excessive lattice distortion of the carbon substrate. However, there remains a significant gap in systematic research regarding the synthesis methods, doping efficiency, and modulation of active sites in heteroatom-doped carbon materials specifically for 2e− ORR catalysts. Moreover, future research should focus on understanding the interaction between different dopants and the carbon matrix, as well as developing new synthetic methods to enhance the stability and activity of these catalysts for practical applications. In-depth research on doped carbon materials is expected to further increase their catalytic performance, reduce costs, and expand application fields. 3.1.2 Oxygen-functional group modification Recent studies indicate that modifying the OFGs is one of the simplest and most cost-effective methods to enhance the ability of carbonaceous materials to generate H2O2. The presence of oxygen species can regulate the electronic structure of adjacent carbon atoms, thereby controlling the binding energy of OOH*. This effect is primarily observed in the influence of OFGs on the surface of carbon-based materials concerning H2O2 activity and selectivity [77,90,91]. For example, the introduction of OFGs (such as COOH, COO, and CO) can provide surface active sites for the 2e− ORR, alter the electronic structure, and adjust the adsorption energy of OOH*. Additionally, this modification can improve the hydrophilicity of the carbon material and impart excellent physical and electrochemical surface properties to the electrode [55]. In the ORR process, an investigation into the edge sites of carbon-supported single-atom catalysts (SACs) reveals that the presence of OFGs can significantly enhance long-term catalytic kinetics and activity [53]. As illustrated in Fig. 3 (a), the presence of Co single atoms on the edge-rich Co-N/HPC was evident. Under prolonged ORR processes, the edges underwent modifications due to various OFGs, resulting in four optimized structural models, as shown in Fig. 3(b). The volcano plot indicated that the combination of OFGs with edge-rich Co-N4 sites on Co-N/HPC promotes reaction kinetics by adjusting the binding energy of OOH* to a more favorable state for the 2e− ORR, as illustrated in Fig. 3(c). Furthermore, the type and content of OFGs introduced significantly influenced the 2e− activity. For instance, carbon nanocage structures with varying OFGs content/types and Co nanoparticles (Co-NPs) content were synthesized [56]. Due to the difference in charge density within the CoGCOC structure, electrons predominantly accumulate on the carbon atoms, resulting in the transfer of electrons from Co atoms to carbon atoms. When OOH* adsorbs onto a carbon atom, the accumulated electrons will transfer to OOH*, facilitating the formation of CO bonds and subsequently generating H2O2. Conversely, no significant charge transfer between OOH* and carbon atoms is observed in GCOC (Fig. 3d). Furthermore, as illustrated in Fig. 3(e), the proportion of COC groups demonstrated a positive correlation with H2O2 selectivity. Hence, the P-Co@C-700 catalyst exhibited an impressive 94% H2O2 selectivity in 0.1 M HClO4 through a 2e− ORR. Notably, P-Co@C-700 facilitated the near-complete removal of rhodamine B (20 mg L−1) at 0.5 V, highlighting the excellent potential of this catalyst for the EF process. It is noteworthy that OFGs not only regulate electronic properties but also enhance the physical and electrochemical characteristics of modified electrodes. For instance, synthesizing an OCNTs/CF cathode using acid-oxidized carbon nanotubes (OCNTs) for carbon felt (CF) modification increased the abundance of oxygen-containing groups compared to a CNTs/CF cathode [92]. The presence of COC and COO groups reduced the η associated with the binding of reaction intermediates during H2O2 generation, establishing them as primary sites for the 2e− ORR. Concurrently, OFGs significantly decreased the water contact angle on the surface of the OCNTs/CF cathode, thereby enhancing its hydrophilicity and facilitating mass transfer, which leads to a substantial production of H2O2. Unlike the preparation methods of heteroatom-doped catalysts, the catalysts prepared by OFGs modification often undergo oxidation or sulfonation with acids or bases. Therefore, to preserve the content of functional groups, the thermal treatment temperature of the catalysts is relatively low. Moreover, OFGs are usually introduced at the edge sites of the carbon substrate, resulting in poor stability of the catalysts and limiting their practical applications. Due to the variety of OFGs, it is essential to systematically investigate the effects of different OFGs on the 2e− ORR by employing advanced in-situ testing techniques. This approach will facilitate the establishment of a correlation between OFGs and catalytic activity. While OFGs may enhance catalytic activity, they can also affect stability. Therefore, it is crucial to precisely control both the types and concentrations of OFGs, as well as to optimize the structure of carbon materials, in order to achieve an optimal balance between stability and activity. Additionally, innovative synthetic techniques can be developed to examine the impact of various precursors and synthetic conditions on the formation of OFGs, thereby optimizing the synthesis process and enabling the controllable selection of OFGs. 3.2 Transition metal-based catalysts The majority of carbon-based materials in previous studies have primarily included graphite, porous carbons, carbon nanotubes, and graphene [93–95]. In addition to carbon-based catalysts, transition metal-based catalysts have garnered significant attention and are frequently employed as nanomaterials due to their abundant availability, low cost, high activity, selectivity, and relative stability [90]. During the Fenton process, the microstructure and composition of the catalyst play a crucial role in the electrochemical synthesis of H2O2 via the ORR. Therefore, regulating the morphology and composition of transition metal-based catalysts can significantly enhance their activity, thereby improving catalytic efficiency. 3.2.1 Structural regulation The appropriate morphology and structure not only enhance the active surface area, providing more active sites for improved H2O2 generation, but also facilitate the mass transfer rate of reactants such as O2 and OOH* within the system. Furthermore, morphology and structure play a significant role in enhancing skeletal stability [96,97]. According to their morphological characteristics, electrocatalysts are typically classified into zero-dimensional (0D), one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D), and three-dimensional (3D) structures. The dimension of an electrocatalyst significantly influences its catalytic performance. 0D electrocatalysts are generally nanoparticles, characterized by spherical or near-spherical shapes. They possess a high surface area and small size effects, often exhibiting a high degree of agglomeration due to their small size and elevated surface energy. In contrast, 1D electrocatalysts, such as nanowires or nanotubes, facilitate charge transport along their length, thereby accelerating electrocatalytic reactions compared to 0D structures. Typical 2D electrocatalysts include sheet graphene materials and transition metal nanosheets, which are atomically thick yet can extend laterally over large areas. Their unique structural features, such as easily modified defects and active edge sites, are critical for enhancing catalytic sites, with edge sites being particularly active for electrocatalytic oxygen reactions. 3D structural electrocatalysts comprise interconnected networks, hollow or porous structures, or hierarchical configurations. Compared to 0D, 1D, and 2D electrocatalysts, 3D electrocatalysts offer numerous advantages, including a significantly increased specific surface area that provides more active sites. The 3D framework also facilitates more efficient electron pathways, enhances mass and nucleus transfer processes, and improves structural stability. The preparation of 3D electrocatalysts can integrate multiple structural designs to create complex morphologies, allowing for the incorporation of different materials into a single catalyst to achieve synergistic effects. Importantly, 3D electrocatalysts facilitate the construction of a gas–liquid-solid three-phase reaction interface, which enhances mass transfer, improves reaction kinetics, and promotes the ORR process. In three-phase system, the gas phase (O2) interacts directly with the liquid phase (electrolyte) and solid phase (electrocatalyst). This configuration allows for more efficient contact between reactants, as O2 must diffuse from the gas phase to the liquid phase and subsequently be adsorbed onto the catalyst surface, where the ORR occurs. The intrinsic high surface area and abundance of active sites in 3D electrocatalysts enhance the adsorption and activation of O2 molecules, reduce the diffusion path for reactants, and consequently accelerate reaction kinetics. Additionally, the three-phase interface significantly mitigates the concentration polarization problem. By ensuring a continuous supply of O2 at the interface, the system maintains a higher reactant concentration at the catalytic site, thereby increasing the reaction rate and overall efficiency. Accordingly, this section primarily discusses the design and regulation of 3D electrocatalysts. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), a highly crystalline, honeycomb-like hexagonal nanosheet cathode (CoFe-LDH) was synthesized, featuring flower-like structures that self-assemble into uniform and porous nanolayers [98]. The degradation rate of 0.1 mM norfloxacin (NFXN) reached 100% within 30 min when CoFe-LDH employed as the working electrode in the EF system. This configuration not only facilitated greater exposure of active sites but also accelerated the rapid transfer of reactive oxygen species, demonstrating exceptional catalytic activity and structural stability. Additionally, a recently reported cost-effective transition metal sulfide catalyst (Mn-CuS-2), synthesized through a hydrothermal reaction, exhibits a coral-like hierarchical porous structure [99]. In electrocatalytic processes, it demonstrated a H2O2 selectivity of up to 92% with a yield exceeding 24.5 mM. This hierarchical macropore structure (0.057 cm3 g−1) and enhanced specific surface area (17.13 m2 g−1) facilitated the construction of the gas–liquid-solid three-phase reaction interface, providing more potential reaction sites and diffusion pathways, thereby promoting mass transfer and surface chemical reactions, ultimately leading to improved catalytic activity. The in situ growth of 3D, amorphous low-coordinated CoS x nanosheets on Cu nanowires (NWs) resulted in Cu NWs being overlaid by thin and small nanosheets (Fig. 4b) [48]. The Cu NWs served as high-conductivity carriers for charge transfer to the 3D CoS x matrix, which contains numerous active sites. Furthermore, hollow structures exhibit properties akin to those of layered structures, which enhance the exposure of active sites and facilitate rapid mass transfer, thereby improving apparent activity. For instance, hollow Zn-N2O2-S SACs (CSH-600) were synthesized as the catalytic cathode, characterized by a thin-walled hollow structure with an approximate diameter of 20 nm, as shown in Fig. 4(c) [100]. The hollow structure of the Zn-N2O2-S SACs had been shown to expedite O2 transport, with uniquely fully exposed Zn sites rapidly reducing O2 to H2O2. This configuration demonstrated exceptional 2e− ORR performance, achieving a high selectivity of 96% for H2O2, along with rapid reaction kinetics and long-term usability. Recently, the core–shell structure has been widely reported to exhibit excellent catalytic performance for electrochemical reactions [101]. Li et al. developed a novel ferromanganese/graphite felt (Fe-Mn/GF) composite cathode, which demonstrates that the Fe-Mn catalyst with a core–shell structure features a dark center and shallow edges [102]. This configuration allowed for a more uniform distribution of the Fe-Mn catalyst on the GF surface, resulting in the formation of numerous active sites for oxygen adsorption and reduction. This promoted the adsorption of more oxygen diffusing from the gas phase to the liquid phase onto the catalyst surface, shortening the diffusion path of reactants and accelerating reaction kinetics, thereby enhancing the in-situ generation of H2O2. The degradation efficiency of various phenolic compounds can reach 100%, and it still showed high catalytic activity (86.5%) after five consecutive runs. The slight decrease in catalytic efficiency may be due to the target pollutants adsorbing on the catalytic sites, blocking active sites, and changes in the acidity or alkalinity of the electrolyte during prolonged catalysis, which further affects the activation efficiency of H2O2. Additionally, Du et al. synthesized a hybrid octahedron with a core–shell structure (Fe/Fe3C@PC) using a one-step hydrothermal method, where iron-based nanoparticles (Fe/Fe3C) are capped by graphitized porous carbon (PC) shells for the degradation of sulfamethazine (SMT) [103]. The removal rate of SMT (10 mg L−1 in 200 mL) attained 99% within 30 min at 25 mA. Furthermore, Fan et al. prepared Fe0/Mn0@Fe/Mn oxide bimetallic nanocomposites (C-nZVIM) with a core–shell structure, employing them as novel heterogeneous EF catalysts for the treatment of methylene blue (MB)-containing wastewater [104]. The core–shell structure of C-nZVIM provided excellent encapsulation, effectively addressing the issue of metal ion leaching commonly seen in metal-based electrocatalysts. Studies have demonstrated that C-nZVIM displays outstanding stability within an extensive pH range (2.5–8.0). This implies that the catalyst is capable of maintaining an efficient working state in various acidic and alkaline environments and adapting to different industrial wastewater treatment demands. This feature not only improves the stability and service life of the catalyst but also mitigates the potential pollution risks to the environment. The aforementioned examples demonstrate that Fenton catalysts featuring core–shell structures possess distinct advantages and exceptional stability within the EF system. However, the core–shell structure often serves as a barrier, limiting the interaction between reactants and consequently diminishing catalytic performance. Thus, it is imperative to carefully regulate both the porosity and thickness of the shell during the design of core–shell catalysts [105]. For example, the optimal core–shell nanocatalyst (Fe/C@mSiO2) was synthesized by encapsulating the thermal decomposition products of MIL-88B(Fe) derivatives within mesoporous SiO2 (mSiO2) (Fig. 4d) [106]. In comparison to the Fe/C catalyst lacking a core–shell configuration, Fe/C@mSiO2 demonstrated a significantly higher specific surface area (514.1 m2 g−1) and a greater pore volume (0.73 cm3 g−1). When Fe/C@mSiO2 was utilized as a heterogeneous electrocatalyst for the degradation of BPA, it successfully achieved complete removal of BPA at 100 mA, with only 0.11 mg L−1 of iron dissolving from the catalyst. The robust mSiO2 shell not only safeguarded the iron active sites from leaching and enhanced activity stability but also offered porous and permeable channels that facilitated efficient mass transfer. Its unique core–shell structure concentrates catalytic sites and reactants in a confined space, promoting rapid degradation of BPA and confirming the high activity and stability of Fe/C@mSiO2. Array structures can also enhance the 2e− ORR for metal catalysts. Several recent studies have demonstrated that the large specific surface area and linear electron transport properties of mesoporous nanorod arrays contribute significantly to improved electrocatalytic activity [107]. In this context, Shi et al. employed Cu foam (CF) as the source of Cu, resulting in the formation of rough and porous Cu2O/CuO composite nanorod array structures on its surface [108]. Cu x O NRs/CF-300 °C possessed a larger pore volume (1.24 × 10−2 cm3 g−1) and specific surface area (1.73 m2 g−1). This approach significantly increased the pore volume, pore size, and specific surface area of CF, thereby providing a greater number of active sites for catalytic processes. This enhanced mass transfer during the adsorption of oxygen and organic pollutants, ensuring a continuous supply of substances like oxygen at the three-phase reaction interface. It maintained high reactant concentrations at catalytic sites, ultimately improving the electrode's catalytic performance. In the electrolyte with a pH value of 5.6, 99.6% of sulfamethoxazole (SMX) was eliminated within 75 min. A novel MoCoFe LDH nanorod array catalyst, prepared via the solvothermal method with the introduction of Mo, features a substantial number of smooth hexagonal nanosheets uniformly arranged on the NF substrate [109]. This open structure offers a larger active surface area compared to the aggregated structure of CoFe LDN/NF. Additionally, the nano-wire array structure exhibited by Mo1CoFe LDH and Mo2CoFe LDH further increases the electrochemical site density and accessibility of active solutes. As shown in Fig. 4(e), the addition of Mo significantly increased the lengths of adjacent CoCo and CoFe bonds, indicating the presence of stretching strains of bonds in the MoCoFe LDH. Concurrently, O2 on Co sites after Mo introduction formed OOH* with a downslope energy of 0.76 eV, which is lower than that for Co (0.85 eV) and Fe (0.98 eV) sites in CoFe LDH (Fig. 4f). These results suggested that the electronic structure adjustment and bond stretching induced by Mo incorporation can facilitate the formation of H2O2 on the surface of MoCoFe LDH. The ORR activity of transition metal-based catalysts is significantly influenced by the regulation of their morphology and structure. However, current challenges include the difficulty in precisely controlling catalyst morphology and a limited understanding of the relationship between structure and performance. Therefore, further in-depth research into the mechanisms of morphology and structure regulation is essential for optimizing catalyst performance. 3.2.2 Component regulation For transition metal-based catalysts, compositional regulation, in addition to morphological control, can significantly enhance metal activity. Consequently, metal single-atoms or metal compound catalysts have emerged as innovative 2e− ORR catalysts with diverse and tunable structures for optimizing H2O2 electrosynthesis [110]. Metal-based SACs are particularly noted for their exceptional ion utilization, intrinsic activity, and selectivity, which have led to their increasing popularity in Fenton systems [111,112]. In the design of non-noble metal SACs, the coordination configuration directly influences reaction activity and product selectivity. As depicted in Fig. 5 (a), models for (O,N)-coordinated Co SAC (Co-N3O) and (S,N)-coordinated Ni SAC (Ni-N3S), along with Co-N4 and Ni-N4, have been constructed [113]. Compared to the conventional Co-N4 and Ni-N4 sites, Co-N3O (4.13 eV) and Ni-N3S (4.34 eV) are positioned closer to the peak of the volcano plot in Fig. 5(b), demonstrating enhanced adsorption strength for OOH*, which facilitates the protonation of OOH* to produce H2O2. In another study, Pd-N4-CO, Pd-S4-NCO, and Pd-N2O2-C SACs were synthesized using heteroatom-containing ligands and activated carbon [114]. As illustrated in Fig. 5(c and d), for the 2e− pathway at U = 0.7 V, Pd-N4-CO_d exhibited the optimal η and ΔG OOH* value for an ideal 2e− ORR catalyst, achieving nearly 100% selectivity for H2O2. In contrast, when examining the 4e− pathway at U = 1.23 V, Pd-S4-C demonstrated an exothermic process from O2 to OH*. Due to its ability to strongly coordinate with highly electronegative donor atoms (N and O), and weakly with the intermediate OOH*, the Pd center offers uniform active sites, resulting in excellent selectivity and sustainable H2O2 production. Recent advancements in the development of 2e− ORR SACs have demonstrated that transition metal compounds and various multi-metal compounds can effectively facilitate the transfer from 4e− to the 2e− process. This transition underscores their high selectivity and catalytic activity for H2O2 electrosynthesis [115,116]. The compound Pd-Se-BNC, synthesized by Lee et al., consists of a mixture of Pd17Se15 and Pd3B. It has demonstrated notable differences in the ORR pathway when compared to conventional Pd metal catalysts [117]. Notably, Pd-Se-BNC exhibits improved selectivity for the 2e− ORR and achieves a higher current density in near-neutral electrolytes. Its H2O2 yield is approximately 37 times greater than that of the Pd black catalyst, which retains nearly 100% selectivity for the 4e− ORR. Additionally, a series of spinel catalysts CuCo2− x Ni x S4 (0 ≤ x ≤ 1.2) for 2e− ORR process were designed [118]. These catalysts exhibited a selectivity exceeding 60%, with activity improvements attainable through increased nickel content without sacrificing selectivity. Following acid treatment, the optimized CuCo0.8Ni1.2S4 catalyst can accumulate up to 84 ppm of H2O2 within 90 min. Furthermore, cobalt sulfides, which are prevalent transition metal compounds located in the Earth's crust, show considerable promise for the electrocatalytic generation of H2O2 due to their unique structural properties. For example, CoS2 nanomaterials exhibit approximately 70% selectivity for H2O2 and demonstrate good operational stability in acidic solutions (0.05 M H2SO4) [119]. This stability is attributed to the moderate binding of the OOH* intermediate at individual cobalt sites, as well as the kinetically unfavorable cleavage of the OO bond. The rational design described above aims to enhance the practical application of Fenton catalysts by the 2e− ORR in wastewater treatment. The parameters for the degradation of organic pollutants and the activities of the electrocatalysts reported recently are presented in Table 1 . Notably, compared to transition metal-based catalysts, carbon-based catalysts typically contain little to no metal content, thereby avoiding the generation of metal sludge and minimizing secondary pollution. Additionally, carbon-based catalysts exhibit a high specific surface area and enhanced stability in electrochemical reactions. However, the intrinsic activity of carbon-based catalysts is often limited, necessitating the functionalization or doping with heteroatoms, which complicates their preparation process. In contrast, transition metal-based catalysts typically exhibit high intrinsic activity, but suffer from poor stability and are susceptible to dissolution under electrochemical conditions. Consequently, enhancing the crystallinity of metal compounds is essential to improve their stability. Furthermore, metal compounds possess diverse morphologies and enable the easy design and regulation of structures. Therefore, the combination of carbon-based materials and transition metals to prepare composite catalysts to take advantage of the synergistic effect is very promising in the field of EF catalysis. Despite the rapid advancements in carbon-based and transition metal-based electrocatalysts in recent years, their durability is restricted by numerous factors during the actual operation of the EF reaction. For instance, metal-based electrocatalysts are susceptible to the leaching of metal ions, which diminishes the number of active sites and subsequently lowers the overall catalytic activity. Additionally, a hydrated oxide layer may develop on the electrocatalyst surface, inhibiting the reaction kinetics. In the presence of multiple pollutants, competition for adsorption sites on the electrocatalyst can hinder the degradation of the target pollutant. Furthermore, fluctuations in pH during continuous operation may decrease the activation efficiency of H2O2. Continuous operation also results in the accumulation of by-products on the electrode surface, which increases resistance and decreases current efficiency. Therefore, the development of highly active and stable non-noble metal electrocatalysts has consistently been a highly anticipated focus in the field of EF technology. 4 Optimization of reaction conditions In EF applications, the electro-generation of H2O2 is the fundamental reaction of the Fenton process, often determining the efficiency of EF degradation. The efficient electrocatalytic production of H2O2 has emerged as a critical research topic within the field of EF. Moreover, when the pH of the electrolyte approaches neutrality or becomes alkaline, Fe2+ in the Fenton reagent can form complex precipitates with hydroxide ions. This interaction adversely affects the conversion efficiency of H2O2 to OH and significantly reduces EF performance [71]. Therefore, enhancing the cyclic regeneration of Fe2+ and broadening the pH range represent effective strategies to improve EF efficiency. 4.1 Improve Fe2+ regeneration In the traditional EF system, the commonly used Fenton reagent is Fe2+. The regeneration of Fe2+ primarily occurs at the cathode and is facilitated by the application of a cathodic potential. When Fe3+ is generated during the oxidation of organic pollutants, it can be reduced back to Fe2+ at the cathode. Thus, Fe2+ undergoes a Fe2+/Fe3+ cycle while activating H2O2. Consequently, the regeneration of Fe2+ is a crucial factor in the conversion of H2O2 into OH [46]. However, the kinetics of the reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+ is relatively slow, which may lead to the accumulation of Fe3+ in the system. This accumulation can result in the formation of iron sludge, thereby inhibiting the overall efficiency of the EF process. Furthermore, the presence of competitive reactions can also impact the regeneration efficiency of Fe2+. For instance, an excess of Fe2+ may induce side reactions that consume reactants without facilitating the oxidation of pollutants. Additionally, in practical applications, factors such as current density and electrode materials can further influence the regeneration efficiency of Fe2+. Therefore, due to the rapid consumption of Fe2+ for H2O2 activation and the slower rate of its regeneration, this process significantly restricts the continuous generation of OH, serving as the RDS that limits overall degradation efficiency [45]. The current predominant method for regenerating Fe2+ involves the use of auxiliary catalysts [123,124], such as organic acids [125–127], and metal sulfides [128–130]. These catalysts facilitate the reduction of Fe3+ by either supplying electrons to Fe3+ complexes or enhancing electron transfer. However, this process faces challenges associated with the collection and recycling of auxiliary catalysts, as well as the introduction of organic reducing agents, which may scavenge active free radicals or compete with target pollutants for OH. These limitations inevitably result in increased treatment costs and secondary pollution, thereby restricting the large-scale application [131]. Consequently, it is essential to design a catalyst that can directly accelerate electron transfer to Fe3+ and facilitate the regeneration of Fe2+. In light of this, a hollow porous carbon spheres (HPCS) catalyst utilizing SiO2 as a hard template has been proposed to enhance the regeneration of Fe2+ through the rational regulation of the surface curvature [52]. As illustrated in Fig. 6 (a and b), the unique large surface curvature of HPCS-TPOS fosters a highly conducive electron microenvironment, thereby accelerating the reduction process from Fe3+ to Fe2+. This enhancement significantly improves the regenerative activity of HPCS-TPOS for Fe2+, consequently facilitating continuous OH generation. HPCS-TPOS removed approximately 100% of SMX within 15 min under a Fe2+ concentration of 0.8 mmol L−1. Furthermore, inorganic compounds, including black phosphorus, zero-valent metals, and boron powder, which feature numerous reduction sites, can enhance the cycling of Fe2+/Fe3+ in the homogeneous EF system. These compounds serve as effective Fenton catalysts by supplying an adequate supply of electrons [130]. Alternatively, the inclusion of active metals (e.g., Cu, Co, Mn) not only accelerates the cycling process of Fe2+/Fe3+, but also acts as catalysts that promote the activation of H2O2 into OH. This dual action further enhances the performance of the EF process while simultaneously increasing the rate of Fe2+ regeneration [132,133]. Recent research has identified direct S modification as an effective strategy for accelerating the Fe2+/Fe3+ cycle by leveraging the high electron capacity of low-valent S [134]. Consequently, the sulfation of Cu-doped MIL-88B(Fe) was proposed to obtain a new heterogeneous EF catalyst (Cu0.5Fe2.5S4) to address the RDS for the regeneration of Fe2+ in the system [120]. In the S/Cu-mediated electron donor shuttling mechanism, S2− served as electron donors while Cu species functioned as electron shuttles. This interaction facilitated the cycling of Fe2+/Fe3+ and ensured a sustainable reduction capacity (Fig. 6c). Naproxen (0.06 mM) can be completely removed within 60 min at 50 mA, thereby enhancing the efficacy of high-performance organic wastewater purification. Notably, the conventional Fenton system excessively inhibits the hydrogen production reaction and overlooks the significance of active hydrogen (H*) in the reduction of Fe3+. Thus, a strategy for H* regulation can be developed by controlling the loading of MoS2 on the GF surface, where H* and H2O2 are produced through the reduction of H+ and O2, respectively [135]. The strong reducing potential of H*, activated by moderate MoS2 loading, significantly accelerates the reduction of Fe3+ to facilitate the regeneration of Fe2+ during the EF process (Fig. 6d). This approach has demonstrated that the concentrations of Fe2+ and OH can be maintained at elevated levels for an extended duration, thereby significantly enhancing the degradation process. The enhancement of Fe2+ generation within the EF system indicates an improvement in the activation reaction of H2O2. It is essential to increase the regeneration rate of Fe2+ through various reaction pathways to facilitate pollutant removal, thereby enhancing the overall performance of the EF system. Therefore, the recycling of Fe2+ in EF studies should not be neglected. 4.2 Regulate reaction pH In the EF system, stringent pH requirements are imposed on the recycling of Fe2+/Fe3+. The EF process typically necessitates operation under highly acidic conditions to prevent the complexation and precipitation of Fe2+/Fe3+, which leads to the formation of iron sludge and significantly hinders the practical applicability of this technology [136]. In recent years, numerous studies have explored non-iron-based Fenton reagents as alternatives to the Fe2+/Fe3+ cycling system. These research aims to expand the operational pH range of EF processes, enabling their application under near-neutral or even strongly alkaline conditions. Such substitutions are intended to minimize the formation of complex metal precipitates, enhance the activation reaction of H2O2, and increase the yield of OH, thereby improving the efficiency of the EF process [137,138]. Currently, a considerable amount of research is also focused on heterogeneous EF processes, thereby broadening the pH range. In this context, active metals are primarily sourced from transition metal species immobilized on the surfaces of multiphase EF catalysts in solid forms. Among these catalysts, H2O2 is predominantly formed and activated at the liquid–solid interface, which helps reduce metal leaching [139]. Therefore, in addition to introducing non-iron-based catalysts, the design of heterogeneous catalysts represents a crucial strategy for extending the applicable pH range of EF operation. In the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts, transition metal/carbon (TM/C) materials are predominantly utilized for the synthesis of multiphase EF catalysts [140–142]. The transition metal and carbon matrix function as active sites for multiphase Fenton reactions and 2e− ORR, respectively. In addition, the carbon matrix loads TM particles and facilitates their electron transfer. For instance, a Cu-Fe2O3/EGF electrode was prepared for in situ generation and activation of H2O2 during heterogeneous EF process to efficiently degrade SMX [19]. The removal rate of SMX reached 100.0% within 90 min at a current density of 6.0 mA cm−2. The results demonstrated that the electrode possesses a wide applicable pH range (3.0–9.0) and exhibits low metal ion leaching, along with stable repeatability after 10 cycles. This effectively prevented iron sludge formation and indicated excellent long-term degradation capability for SMX. In another study, Yu et al. developed a nanosheet structure (CoFe-LDH/CF) cathode for the removal of NFXN [98]. The mineralization efficiency of NFXN was significantly improved over a wide pH range of 3.0–9.0, reaching at least 90%. The excellent catalytic activity remained above 97% after 5 cycles experiments, demonstrating good reusability. Nevertheless, the direct exposure of TM materials to the electrolyte makes them susceptible to oxidation, detachment, or dissolution, which leads to catalytic deactivation [143]. Hence, the adoption of an encapsulated structure comprising a porous carbon layer and a TM core (TM@C) presents a promising strategy for immobilizing TM components. This approach effectively prevents the leaching of metal ions from the catalytic surface and enhances cycling stability without significantly compromising the selectivity for the ORR [65,144]. For instance, CuFe2O4@CS microspheres were synthesized as precursors for high-temperature pyrolysis, resulting in the formation of Cu-Fe-Fe3C@NDB encapsulated structures [63]. Interestingly, the removal rate of organic pollutants (100 mg L−1) can reach 99.3% within 35 min in a neutral electrolyte at 12 mA cm−2, which can be maintained for more than 10 cycles. This configuration minimizes the loss of active metal components and maintains a low level of ionic metals, thereby enabling wide pH applicability and excellent stability while preventing the formation of metal sludge. However, compared to the TM/C configuration, the TM@C structure exhibits lower metal accessibility and a hindered mass transfer rate. If the porosity and thickness of the outer carbon layer are not precisely controlled, the original Fenton activity of the metal core may be significantly impaired. Cheng et al. successfully encapsulated the highly active iron phosphide composite (Fe x P/C) within an ultrathin layer of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) [145]. Variations in the thickness of the rGO layers indicated that the outer rGO layer functions as a high-speed channel, enhancing the Fe2+/Fe3+ cycling within the internal Fe x P/C system. This configuration facilitates the transfer of electrons from structural Feδ+ (0 < δ+ < 2) to surface-bound Fe3+ (Fig. 7 a). Additionally, carbon cloth-loaded ferric oxychloride (FeOCl/CC) was effectively wrapped in the rGO protective layer (FeOCl/CC@rGO) using an electrophoretic method [146]. The OH generation pathway of the composite cathode can transition from a pH-sensitive liquid-phase activation mechanism to a pH-independent surface catalytic mechanism. The total leaching of Fe within the pH range of 3.0–7.0 is merely 0.57% of FeOCl/CC. This minimal leaching significantly enhances the stability of the composite cathode while maintaining its activity. Consequently, this achieves an equilibrium between activity and stability in functional cathodes for the heterogeneous EF process. In addition to the encapsulation of metals within catalysts through specialized structures, the acidic microenvironment on the surfaces of heterogeneous catalysts can effectively alleviate pH limitations. A recent study demonstrated the sustainable degradation of organic pollutants using a MoS2 co-catalyzed heterogeneous Fenton system (CoFe2O4/MoS2) in a neutral buffer solution [71]. It was observed that the unsaturated sulfur at the edges of MoS2 exhibited proton bonding properties, facilitating the formation of an acidic microenvironment on the surface of CoFe2O4 through chemical interactions with MoS2. On the other hand, Co-based TM catalysts, including sulfides, oxides, selenides, phosphides, and carbides, are a notable class of non-noble metal ORR catalysts due to their unique redox properties and electronic configurations [147–149]. Among these, CoS2 has attracted considerable attention compared to other semiconducting TM sulfides due to its high conductivity. In the study by Chen et al., a cost-effective amorphous electrocatalyst (CoS x (t = 8)@Cu) was synthesized using a straightforward ethanol-assisted electrodeposition method [121]. The acidic microenvironment on the surface of CoS x (t = 8)@Cu was established via the H*/H+ process, facilitating a self-regulating transition from alkalinity to acidity during the EF reaction. This phenomenon effectively suppressed the formation of iron sludge while enhancing the regeneration of Fe2+ (Fig. 7b). Thus, it is evident that in the EF reaction, the acidic microenvironment not only extends the applicability of Fenton technology but also significantly enhances the regeneration rate of Fe2+. It should be emphasized that the pH of the solution and the concentrations of Fe2+ and Fe3+ significantly influence the formation of iron sludge. The low recyclability of Fe2+/Fe3+ can lead to the accumulation of Fe3+, thereby accelerating the generation of iron sludge and reducing the stability of the EF system. Effective strategies to mitigate iron sludge production include employing separate electrolytic cells to isolate the anode and cathode reactions, as well as adjusting the pH to minimize the requirement for additional acid or alkali reagents. Furthermore, most heterogeneous catalysts demonstrate minimal metal ion leaching and exhibit excellent stability and repeatability, even after multiple operational cycles across a wide pH range. This effectively prevents the formation of iron sludge, reduces economic costs, and significantly enhances both the ORR performance and chemical stability in heterogeneous EF processes. Finally, effective monitoring and control of operational parameters, such as current density and the concentrations of H2O2 and Fe2+, can maximize the generation of OH while minimizing the formation of unwanted by-products, including iron sludge. 5 Coupling techniques The hybrid EF process has garnered significant attention in recent years due to its ability to integrate the advantages of various conventional treatment methods, including adsorption, biological treatment, and filtration. This integration facilitates the efficient removal of organic pollutants. Consequently, in the pursuit of developing catalytic materials with superior performance and optimizing reaction conditions to enhance EF efficiency, the EF process can be effectively combined with other biological, chemical, and physical technologies. Such coupling aims to achieve more efficient wastewater treatment and further enhance the performance of the EF process. 5.1 Microbial electro-Fenton (MBEF) The MBEF system has garnered significant attention for its role in the degradation of organic matter, primarily due to its inherent self-powered advantage [150]. In comparison to conventional EF, MBEF combines the cost-effectiveness of a biological treatment system with the robust oxidative capacity of EF, making it an effective alternative for addressing limitations such as a narrow pH range, high energy consumption, and low removal rates [151]. Currently, the MBEF system consists primarily of an anode chamber and a cathode chamber. The underlying principle of pollutant degradation is similar to that of the EF process (Fig. 8 a) [152]. Electrons generated by microorganisms under anaerobic conditions in the anode chamber are transported to the cathode chamber through the microbial metabolism of substrates. These electrons can be utilized by various terminal electron acceptors to facilitate the 2e− reaction at the cathode, followed by the Fenton reaction in the presence of an iron source, which generates the Fenton reagent required for the oxidation of organic matter [153]. For instance, a two-compartment MBEF system was constructed with a biological anode and O-doped metal-free OCNT-80/CB as a Fenton cathode, achieving a cathodic tetracycline (TC) removal efficiency of up to 97.6% [154]. DFT calculations revealed that the ORR process was primarily controlled by the reduction and desorption steps of OH*. On the OCNT-80 surface, H2O2* formed *OHCO under the influence of CO, further leading to the formation of OH* to achieve the most stable adsorption configuration. By utilizing OFGs (CO) to sequester oxygen from the environment, a greater number of radicals can participate in the degradation of pollutants. Additionally, an efficient cathode promoted the vitality of anodic microbial communities, while also facilitating in-situ self-driven green energy generation with multiple effects. However, similar to the traditional EF technology, MBEF also encounters the challenge of iron cycling, where the Fe2+/Fe3+ cycling remains the core and rate-limiting step of the cathodic reaction [155]. To address this issue, Chung et al. employed MBEF in conjunction with microbial iron cycling to enhance the efficiency of iron cycling and reduce overall iron consumption [152]. The results indicated a 22.2% increase in H2O2 production, while the TC removal rates improved by 23.9%, 22.8%, and 32.6% for concentrations of 10 mg L−1 (70.3 ± 1.0%), 20 mg L−1 (84.0 ± 0.4%), and 50 mg L−1 (68.4 ± 0.1%), respectively. Notably, the Fe2+ recycling rate ranged from 79.8% to 84.1%, significantly surpassing that of the control group. Furthermore, energy consumption was considerably lower when compared to the EF system. In a separate study, Fe3+-containing slow-release spheres were prepared through polymer encapsulation and subsequently introduced into the anode chamber of the MBEF [156]. Within this configuration, microorganisms facilitated the reduction of Fe3+ from the slow-release spheres to Fe2+, which was then transported to the cathode chamber via an exchange membrane to activate the in situ-generated H2O2. The removal rate of TC and the loss of iron sources were superior to those observed in conventional MBEF, which involves the direct addition of cathodic Fe2+. This indicated that the anodic slow-release and self-generated Fe2+ MBEF demonstrates enhanced pollutant removal efficiency, higher utilization rates of iron sources, and greater potential for practical applications. The MBEF system, which incorporates microbial action, reduces the reliance on chemical agents, lowers costs, and enhances degradation efficiency, presents significant advantages over EF technology in wastewater treatment. However, the inclusion of microbial cultivation and management adds complexity to the system. Furthermore, the growth of bacterial communities necessitates stringent environmental conditions within the wastewater, which may impact treatment effectiveness. Therefore, further advancements in MBEF could provide innovative approaches for the efficient and energy-saving operation of the EF technique. Key areas for improvement include optimizing microbial communities, screening for highly efficient degrading strains, and enhancing overall treatment efficiency. Furthermore, conducting in-depth research into the synergistic mechanisms between microorganisms and electrochemical processes is crucial for refining treatment technologies. 5.2 Electro-Fenton-electrocoagulation (EF-EC) In recent years, the frequent detection of heavy metal–organic complexes in wastewater has emerged as a significant threat to human health. Currently, chemical precipitation and biological treatment are the most commonly employed methods for treating heavy metal-containing wastewater, alongside the development of highly efficient combined technologies [157,158]. Consequently, a novel combination of heterogeneous EF and electrocoagulation processes has been devised to effectively address heavy metal contamination in water. For instance, the degradation of the Cu-ciprofloxacin (Cu-CIP) complex was significantly enhanced using N-doped porous carbon loaded with Co/Fe sites derived from Co/Fe-MIL-101 as the cathode (N-Co/Fe-PC), while aluminum (Al) served as the anode [159]. Under the EF process, the Cu-CIP complex initially degraded into smaller molecules, releasing Cu2+ ions. These released ions were effectively adsorbed by Al hydroxide or hydroxyl oxides, particularly γ-AlOOH generated at the anode, ultimately leading to their co-precipitation. Simultaneously, the Box-Behnken design (BBD) method was applied to investigate the interactions among various influencing factors and to determine the optimal conditions. It can effectively remove the heavy metal salts that are usually resistant to most catalytic materials with a pH value of 6.6 at 140 mA. The optimal removal rates (40 min) for Cu, ciprofloxacin (CIP), and total organic carbon (TOC) reached 99.69%, 96.40%, and 83.62%, respectively, thereby significantly enhancing the wastewater purification efficiency. In another experiment investigating the combined process of EF and EC, the electrochemical destruction of Cu-EDTA complexes and the removal of released Cu2+ ions using iron anodes and stainless steel cathodes were examined [160]. The degradation of Cu-EDTA was primarily attributed to the presence of OH, while the subsequent release of Cu2+ could be effectively mitigated through various methods, including adsorption, coagulation, co-precipitation, and cathodic reduction. Beyond heavy metal–organic compounds, the EF-EC process demonstrates superior treatment efficacy for a range of organic wastewater. For example, the treatment of paper wastewater using the EF-EC process resulted in a reduction of COD from an initial concentration of 1080 to 175 mg L−1 [161]. This coupled approach offers the advantage of reduced energy consumption compared to electrocoagulation or EF alone. Daghrir et al. successfully applied the coupled EF-EC system for efficient domestic wastewater treatment, achieving removal rates of 50.1% for COD, 70.8% for total suspended solids (TSS), and 90.4% for turbidity within a duration of 60 min [162]. Collectively, these studies demonstrate that the combined utilization of EF-EC can achieve treatment effects that surpass those attainable by an independent EF system alone, indicating promising prospects for further development. 5.3 Photoelectro-Fenton (PEF) Among various water treatment technologies, the PEF reaction system, which utilizes light radiation based on EF, is frequently employed as an advanced oxidation process (AOP) [163]. Light radiation enhances the regeneration of Fe2+ by introducing photoelectrons that accelerate the Fe2+/Fe3+ cycle, thereby promoting the generation of OH and the decomposition of H2O2. This effectively combines the benefits of electrocatalysis and photocatalysis, as illustrated in Fig. 8(b) [164,165]. Under the synergistic effect of photoelectricity, the system can efficiently degrade and mineralize organic pollutants, making it a widely adopted practical application method [166,167]. In this context, a chemical-free PEF system was designed for relevant research purposes·H2O2 was generated through electrochemical ORR using a copper hollow-fiber gas-diffusion electrode (Cu-hf-GDE), and was subsequently converted to OH under simulated sunlight irradiation via an intermittent reactor on an effective Fe/CN thin film [164]. The study revealed that the degradation rates of 10 ppm florfenicol varied significantly across different processes, with photolysis, photocatalysis (PC), and EF exhibiting removal rates of 17%, 24%, and 32%, respectively. In contrast, the degradation rate in the PEF system reached 98%, which was considerably higher than the combined rates of the PC and EF processes. This result clearly demonstrates the excellent synergistic effect of PC and EF within the Fenton system. Currently, the utilization of heterogeneous PEF systems has demonstrated significant potential in broadening the applicability of PEF while simultaneously enhancing its performance. Zhang et al. developed a highly active and reusable composite electrode (Fe/C/N@ZIF-8@ACF) for heterogeneous PEF [168]. Under aeration and cathodic illumination conditions, photogenerated OH were produced via a 2e− ORR process on the Fe/C/N. Concurrently, a substantial number of photogenerated electrons accelerated the Fenton reaction, significantly improving the catalytic activity of Fe/C/N@ZIF-8@ACF and effectively enhancing antibiotic degradation rates across a wide pH range.
