Another example is provided by Xin et al., who constructed a heterogeneous visible light-driven PEF system utilizing N/O biomass self-doped porous carbon (NO/PC) in conjunction with CuFeO2/biochar particles for the removal of TC [169]. In this system, electrostatic induction and photoexcitation generate electrons on CuFeO2/biochar, thereby facilitating the redox cycles of Fe2+/Fe3+ and Cu+/Cu2+. This process promotes the formation of H2O2 and enhances the degradation of TC, achieving degradation rates of up to (97.7 ± 0.8%). The PEF process, as an emerging water treatment technology, has the potential to effectively degrade pollutants. However, it also encounters several challenges. The integration of additional light source equipment may complicate the system and increase operational costs, while inadequate light may limit the treatment efficacy. Therefore, enhancing technology and optimizing reaction conditions could further improve its performance and applicability. For instance, investigating more efficient photoelectrocatalysts could enhance photoelectric conversion efficiency and reaction system stability, thereby reducing energy consumption. Additionally, exploring optimal parameters such as light intensity and wavelength could maximize treatment effectiveness. 5.4 Other co-ordination techniques In recent years, there has been considerable interest in enhancing EF efficiency through the use of coupled anodic water oxidation reaction (WOR) or peroxymonosulfate (PMS). In electrocatalytic systems, the cathodic reduction of oxygen (2e− ORR: O2 + 2H+ + 2e− → H2O2) and the anodic water oxidation (2e− WOR: 2H2O → 2H+ + 2e− + H2O2) are coupled to produce H2O2 (Fig. 8c), which is subsequently activated to generate radicals [170]. From an economic and practical perspective, the combination of 2e− ORR with 2e− WOR for H2O2 synthesis or the EF process presents significant potential for application. In this context, an efficient dual-side H2O2 generation system was demonstrated, utilizing an active and stable bifunctional plasma-induced defect TiO2− x (WOR//ORR coupling). This system achieved an impressive H2O2 productivity of up to 20 mmol L−1 h−1 and a Faradaic efficiency of 134%, which significantly enhances the selectivity for the 2e− process [171]. By combining in situ Raman spectroscopy with DFT calculations, the reaction mechanisms of the two catalytic processes on the TiO2(1 0 1) surface were elucidated. The findings revealed that oxygen vacancies at inner-layer atomic sites and surface distortion are respectively responsible for enhancing the performance of the 2e− ORR and 2e− WOR. Additionally, Chu et al. utilized a superhydrophobic carbon cathode, a titanium-based oxide anode, and an FeWO4 catalyst to achieve the complete removal of 40 mg L−1 TC within 60 min. This outcome was attributed to the synergistic effects of the EF and WOR processes [172]. PMS is an asymmetric peroxide that can be activated through energy or electron transfer mechanisms, such as heating, ultraviolet light exposure, and transition metal ions. Its distinctive structure makes it a widely used oxidant for generating SO4 − . Other ROS, O2 − , 1O2 and OH, are also produced during the activation of PMS [173]. Currently, the integration of the EF process with activated PMS technology offers a straightforward, efficient, and cost-effective approach for the removal of recalcitrant organic pollutants from industrial wastewater. This combination provides novel insights into the synergy of various AOPs. For example, the integration of the EF process with zero-valent iron (ZVI) activation of PMS led to the development of a ZVI-E-Fenton-PMS wastewater treatment method [174]. This innovative process not only generates H2O2 and activates PMS at the cathode but also facilitates the reduction of Fe3+, thereby achieving a sustainable Fe2+/Fe3+ redox cycle. As a result, it produced a greater quantity of ROS ( OH, SO4 − , and 1O2), significantly reduced oxidant costs, and enabled rapid pollutant removal. Wang et al. employed the EF-PMS oxidation process to treat MB wastewater [175]. The study demonstrated that OH, SO4 − , and 1O2 were primarily responsible for the generation of ROS in the EF-PMS system. Compared to individual treatments prior to coupling, this combined approach exhibited a significant enhancement in the MB degradation rate, achieving up to 56.84% mineralization within 2 h. In a separate study conducted by Ganiyu et al., the electro-activation of PMS was synergistically coupled with heterogeneous EF catalyzed by iron-modified biochar (BC-Fe), resulting in enhanced degradation and mineralization of organic pollutants [176]. Notably, an efficient removal of 50 mg L−1 of the pollutant was achieved within 30 min. This combination of two distinct processes underscores the application advantages and potential prospects of this technology, thereby demonstrating its excellent suitability for addressing various environmental challenges. It is noteworthy that the coupling technology demonstrates effective treatment outcomes for certain emerging pollutants that are difficult to degrade, including phenolic compounds [177,178], antibiotics [179,180], and herbicides [181,182]. These pollutants are commonly found in industrial and medical wastewater. Their high stability in the environment can lead to accumulation in aquatic ecosystems, resulting in toxic effects on both animals and plants, and potentially entering the human food chain. Traditional wastewater treatment methods primarily target the removal of large volumes of organic matter and pathogens, but they are often insufficient for the effective removal of these challenging pollutants. The integration of EF technology with other treatment methods is particularly advantageous for managing wastewater streams with complex compositions, such as those generated by the textile and pharmaceutical industries. Consequently, coupling technology not only enhances the efficiency of the EF process but also expands its applicability in addressing complex environmental challenges. In general, a variety of coupling techniques have been developed and can be employed in wastewater treatment to expand the application of EF technology. Each coupled technology possesses its own peculiarities. Among them, the PMS-EF process appears to offer the greatest feasibility for industrial applications, as it can generate multiple active radicals, thereby enhancing pollutant degradation efficiency and reducing operational costs. Additionally, the PEF process demonstrates significant potential, particularly for specific pollutants; however, its application may be constrained by the necessity of a light source. The MBEF system, although environmentally friendly, encounters challenges such as complex operation, prolonged start-up times, and the need to sustain microbial activity. The EF-EC technique can not merely handle refractory pollutants but also effectively eliminate suspended solids and heavy metals. These technologies can be selectively employed across various water treatment processes, depending on the specific characteristics of the wastewater and the desired treatment outcomes. Additionally, the choice of new materials is of great significance in improving the efficiency of water treatment. Various types of materials can construct specific active sites under particular conditions, thereby enhancing the reaction rate and selectivity. This not only contributes to enhancing the overall efficiency of the water treatment process but also reduces energy consumption and operational costs, bringing about more substantial economic and environmental benefits to the water treatment industry. 6 Conclusions and outlook As one of the most promising AOPs, EF technology has garnered increasing attention, and its industrial application for treating recalcitrant organic pollutants has been significantly advanced. Consequently, enhancing the activity and stability of 2e− catalytic materials, while improving removal efficiency and reducing treatment costs, has emerged as a primary research direction. However, the current conventional EF process exhibits limited applicability, rendering it unsuitable for large-scale production and application, which impedes the further development of EF technology. Therefore, regulating cathode electrocatalysts and optimizing reaction conditions are key strategies for improving electrochemical efficiency. These efforts aim to deepen our understanding of EF technology and enhance its applicability in wastewater treatment. Several challenges encountered in applied research on EF are highlighted, necessitating increased attention to strengthen its practicality and economic feasibility. As EF technology continues to advance, it holds promise as a widely used, efficient wastewater treatment method that is both environmentally friendly and economically viable. (I) The activity and stability of Fenton catalysts are critical factors in their performance. Many high-activity Fenton catalysts tend to degrade and lose efficacy under harsh electrochemical conditions, resulting in poor long-term operational capability. Factors such as corrosion, surface fouling, changes in chemical properties, and structural damage significantly diminish the lifespan of these catalysts, posing substantial challenges in the EF process. Therefore, it is essential to investigate new catalyst design and regulation strategies, including the use of specialized precursors, improvements in the preparation process, and the construction of unique structures, to enhance both the stability of the catalyst and its catalytic efficiency. Furthermore, the introduction of advanced materials science theories and technological approaches, such as computer-aided design and high-throughput experimental methods, could expedite the discovery and optimization of new catalysts. Continuously seeking breakthroughs and innovations in catalyst design and regulation is both necessary and beneficial. (II) The application of in situ techniques in EF reaction mechanisms research offers significant advantages. Currently, the focus of understanding the reaction mechanism lies in the identification of active sites and the evolution of reactive species. In situ techniques enable real-time, non-destructive characterization of electrochemical reaction processes, providing detailed insights into the dynamics of these reactions by monitoring changes in active sites, the generation of intermediates, and transitions in metal oxidation states. For instance, in situ Raman spectroscopy and in situ infrared spectroscopy are pivotal for the real-time detection of species information, oxidation states, and structural transformations on catalyst surfaces. In situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy and in situ X-ray diffraction are capable of identifying catalyst crystal phase transitions and changes in valence states. Furthermore, in-situ electron microscopy technology has been reported as a tool for studying electrocatalytic mechanisms. Additionally, theoretical calculation simulation plays a crucial role in revealing the reaction mechanism at the theoretical level. These methods enhance our understanding of active sites, elucidate reaction mechanisms, and optimize catalytic performance. However, despite the development of various in situ characterization techniques aimed at elucidating reaction mechanisms, the adoption of these techniques in EF research has not gained widespread popularity. Therefore, it is essential to integrate and popularize in situ characterization methods to deepen our understanding of the EF mechanism. (III) The performance evaluation of EF systems for practical wastewater treatment must consider the specific pollutants present in the production processes of various industries, as these can significantly impact the activity and stability of the catalyst. Additionally, it is essential to comprehensively assess the effects of temperature, pH, and oxygen content on the catalyst, validating these factors in real wastewater treatment scenarios rather than relying solely on theoretical observations. It is recommended to establish evaluation standards for the EF technology in wastewater treatment systems, encompassing catalyst activity and stability, environmental factors, equipment operating costs, and maintenance complexity. Yaqian Wang obtained her bachelor's degree from Henan Agricultural University in 2022 and is currently pursuing a master's degree at Northeast Agricultural University. Her main research focuses on the preparation of carbon-based electrocatalysts for the two-electron (2e−) oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Pengxiang Liu is currently pursuing a master's degree at the Department of Chemistry, Northeast Agricultural University. His primary research is the design of cathode catalysts for zinc-air batteries and the study of oxygen reaction mechanisms. Ruijun Lv is currently a master's student at the Department of Chemistry, Northeast Agricultural University. Her current research interests focus on the preparation of transition metal carbon composite electrocatalysts for the application of electro-Fenton technology. Peng Yu obtained a PhD degree in physical chemistry from Heilongjiang University. After two years of postdoctoral research work at Tsinghua University, she has been an associate professor at the Key Laboratory for Photonic and Electronic Bandgap Materials, Ministry of Education, Harbin Normal University, China. Her current research interests focus on the development of advanced nanomaterials for electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Haiyang Zhang obtained his PhD degree in chemical engineering and technology from Harbin Institute of Technology. He joined Northeast Agricultural University in 2021 and is involved in the synthesis and application of photoelectrocatalytic materials and intelligent bionic materials. Xu Liu obtained a PhD degree from Heilongjiang University under the supervision of Prof. Honggang Fu. Currently, he is an associate professor at the Chemistry Department of the Northeast Agricultural University. His research focuses on the design of non-precious metal electrocatalysts for zinc-air batteries, electro-Fenton technology, and organic oxidation reactions. Lei Wang received her BS degree in 2007 and MS degree in 2010 from Heilongjiang University. In 2013, she received her PhD degree from Jilin University. Then, she joined Heilongjiang University as a lecturer. She became an assistant professor in 2015. Currently, she is a professor at the College of Chemical Engineering and Materials, Heilongjiang University. Her research interests focus on the construction and operando mechanism of electrode materials in electrochemical energy devices.

coredata.dc:description: The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) holds significant potential for various energy conversion and utilization technologies. In particular, the two-electron (2e−) ORR process for the electro-synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) facilitates the continuous production of this compound. Recently, the application of 2e− ORR in electro-Fenton (EF) technology has garnered substantial attention within the wastewater treatment sector. Despite substantial advancements, challenges remain regarding the activity and stability of oxygen reduction catalysts, as well as the specific reaction conditions, which continue to limit the degradation efficiency of EF technology. Therefore, it is essential to examine the progress in research on 2e− oxygen reduction catalysts and the optimization of EF reaction conditions. This review begins by summarizing the fundamental principles of ORR and EF technologies. It discusses the regulatory strategies for carbon-based and transition metal-based catalysts aimed at improving the yield and selectivity of H2O2. Additionally, the optimization methods for EF reaction conditions are outlined, focusing on promoting the regeneration of Fe2+ and broadening the operational pH range. The review further elaborates on novel coupling technologies. Finally, it envisions future research prospects to enhance the practicality and feasibility of EF technology in wastewater treatment.
